Posts.Content: Hi,  I have a PICC lines but have not had an aching arm but I was told by the medical professional if I did get such symptoms to call the triage team as it might be symptoms of a blood clot. Call just to be on the safe side❤️
Posts.Title: Aching arm with PICC

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, I am going for 4th cycle of FEC on Tuesday. I have actually lost weight while on Chemo...I don't think weight gain is inevitable. I would say I eat healthily, avoid sugar etc, and exercise. Yes, steroids do increase your appetite, but I find while on the steroids I don't really want to eat anything, probably the nausea the first few days after infusion.(they do keep me awake all night though) thing is we are all different and side effects are too. I must say that I have found it much harder to bounce back mentally and phsically after this cycle, the cumulative effect, and I am not looking forward to going in for next one...but on we go. Sorry this wasn't really much help Carol xx
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Fiona, Wonderful insight. Beautiful words. Last chemo...bathe in the light, you are at the end of the tunnel! Carol xxx PS loved your letter to myself also.
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi there, I was SO upset to read this post. My advice is to DEMAND a second opinion with A DIFFERENT CONSULTANT AND DONT DELAY. I would have no faith in this man if it were me. He sounds very negative and just awful. Carol Xxx
Posts.Title: Confused after unhelpful consultant appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, We went through DX and treatment on a similar time scale. I too feel very underwhelmed by the lack of follow up care. We have all read about possible long term effects of chemo on the heart, liver, thyroid etc. And was warned about these before I started chemo. My last appointment with the oncologist was very disappointing, he waved his hand and dismissed theses worries and said chemo side effects are short term, no scans, no blood tests, nothing.....its up to you to tell if something is not right!!! Very awe inspiring!  Well, I thought at least I'll go to my doctor and get a full blood screen after the end of chemo, as raised caclium, CEA levels and other things can be detected in the blood. She was very sweet, but to be honest I knew more about breast cancer than she did. However, she agreed that we would do a full blood screen every six months. I feel we all have to be our own advocates. Sadly, we only seem to get somethings if we push for them. I know, after treatment we are to get on with our lives, and I agree with that and I have thought about   stopping visits to this site, as amazing as it has been, and I truly mean that, it also causes anxiousness.  This is new territory, and I guess we have to get used to it and I think it is pretty standard all over the world, I don't think scans are given routinely, after treatment is finished.  Love Carol
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, I know how you feel as my margins were not clear. My surgeon offered to go in and try again but I decided on a mastectomy as I am very small and there was not much tissue left to take so would have looked really odd. Luckily, the nodes were not affected, but the tumor was 3.5 cm on removal so decided to do chemo. Hope you get good news tomorrow. Carol xxxx
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Iona and Fiona, So happy that you are feeling stronger each day now treatment has finished. I will finish soon and have been doing a lot of research into supplements. I am very interested in chlorella, a powder that you can put in oatmeal, shakes etc. It can reduce the effects of chemo and radiation. Check it out if you are interested.❤️ Carol xx
Posts.Title: Vitamins and supplements?

Posts.Content: Hi again Bev, No I do not get this feeling in my head. If it is a concern and doesn't feel right, I know it's hard to tell when nothing feels right!, you should call the triage number especially if it's due to high blood pressure. If it's more like a headache it could be dehydration, to do, do, persevere with the water and get it down you anyway you can, I swear it helps with the side effects. You will start to feel better soon and maybe enjoy that beer! Love Carol xxxx
Posts.Title: Sore mouth

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, I had Fec3 yesterday. I have had no mouth issues yet, but they are not uncommon. Keep using the mouth wash and maybe salt water, if it is real bad, with ulcers, get a prescription. The only thing that tastes really bad for me is water and it is important to drink as much as you can, tea doesn't count I'm afraid, so I boil it and add lemon juice and it tastes better, you should drink about 2L a day.  Love, Carol
Posts.Title: Sore mouth

Posts.Content: Have just spent the last hour reading the thread, Chloe's journey has been inspiring. I wish her well as she follows her own path. It was the post that caused concern, especially as some newly diagnosed, emotionally fragile, might stumble across it.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: This post should be removed it contains many inflammatory and down right inaccurate statements, and is highly irresponsible.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Lavender Girl,   I agree with you totally, the posts of this woman for me are totally negative. Her cancer is her life. I choose to take the treatment and move on! Life is for living without constant appointments and scans to monitor how your cancer is growing. Get it cut out and get on with the life you have and enjoy the moment....because this moment is your life. Carol xxx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Thanks, yes I have decided to go for the pic line. I have seen the ports. My husband had one. That was in Califofrnia though, I am now in the UK and haven't been offered that. You are in Australia, right?  Carolxxx
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Hi there January chemo club.........I will be joining you on the 19th. Was wondering how many of you had pic lines...the team I met REALLY pushed for me to have one. I am wondering if this is because it makes their job easier or they are really a good thing. Any advice will be greatly appreciated. I read your posts everyday and your experiences are very helpful to those of us waiting to join.  Carolxxxx
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: January Club, Thank you all for your posts........I guess my decision is made. Pic line. What would I do without all this support. Thank you Ellen,Liz, Dream Thief, Julia and JediKnight, may the force be with us all! Carolxxxx
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland, I totally agree with Julia, don't worry about things that haven't and might not happen. Take it one side effect at a time. It is a long journey, one step at a time. ❤️ Carol xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland, I totally agree with Julia, don't worry about things that haven't and might not happen. Take it one side effect at a time. It is a long journey, one step at a time. ❤️ Carol xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi, Good luck with your results. As others will post, this can be the most difficult time, the waiting for results. You are already on the roller coaster, emotions and thoughts all over the place. All I can do is give you my opinion, but in the end you have to do what's best for you, because you are the one who must take control. Be kind to yourself. That does not mean you are being selfish. Tell people what YOU want them to know. Those YOU choose to tell, let them know how much YOU want to talk about it. Set your own boundaries. For example, most people diagnosed with cancer don't want to hear about the neighbour who has cancer, because it is not your story and every story is different. I told my best friend right away, because that's the relationship we have. I didn't tell all family members right away, or work colleagues. It's all up to you....be kind to yourself. Love and good luck Carol xxxxx
Posts.Title: Newbie with core biopsy question

Posts.Content: Hi there,  Just wondering if you'd had your mammogram? Did it show anything? Carol xx
Posts.Title: Please....not again

Posts.Content: Hi bubble blower, Well done and a high 5! The road seems so long at the beginning but you got there!  Carol xx
Posts.Title: RIP Cancer 12/04/15---11/02/16 I'm there! LAST TREATMENT TODAY, No...

Posts.Content: A Hi cocopops1 I can only echo all that has been said. It is good advice because we know what we are talking about as we have been there and come through. You can't alter the past so forget about it. The future is unknown not just to you but to everyone, yes we might have to deal with the uncertainty that a cancer diagnosis brings but you will learn to live with it. It's the here and now you must focus on. Day to day. Keep you mind in the light. Your mind is powerful, it will try to pull you into the dark, but think about all the wonderful things that are in your life right now, try to feel some joy everyday. You are going through the worst part, the waiting....with time it will all get better. You are stronger than you think. When you are faced with cancer, you just get on with it, because there is no other choice. Get ready for the rollercoaster ride ahead, don't overwhelm yourself, be kind to yourself you can do this. By the way, my tumour was 35mm! Carolxxxxx
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: You are not alone, we all have fears and anxiety. It is the unknown. The right amount of information gives you power and helps you regain some control. Don't let cancer be the boss. The wonderful women on this site have empowered me. Learn from their experience. Every journey is different but try to face it head on and show it who's boss! And take it one day at a time. Big hug Carolxx
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: You are not alone, we all have fears and anxiety. It is the unknown. The right amount of information gives you power and helps you regain some control. Don't let cancer be the boss. The wonderful women on this site have empowered me. Learn from their experience. Every journey is different but try to face it head on and show it who's boss! And take it one day at a time. Big hug Carolxx
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: HI there, just to add what my oncologist said- the size of the tumor is the least important factor-
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Hi, I just went through a mental list of people I know, meaning I have had some interaction with them, and I count 15 people who have had cancer!!! If I included people I know of ....the number would increase. These do not include blood relatives as I am the first, no cancer on either side of my family. Most of them are still alive so things are looking up! Carol xxx
Posts.Title: How many do you know?

Posts.Content: HI there, just to add what my oncologist said- the size of the tumor is the least important factor-
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, Your words....but there I was in bed after the op looking at my scar straight away and it was ok I'm still me I haven't changed having my breast removed has saved my life and that's what's important.... So simple , so true.  Thanks, Carol xx
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi  I had a mastectomy in December. Physically, there was very little pain. You will have a drain or drains inserted to collect fluids, they are uncomfortable, but not too bad. Mine were only in overnight but some women do have to go home with them, everyone is different. The scar , is a scar, no getting away from it, I felt it looked like I had been bitten by a shark! But it is not as raw looking now. As you say, it is the emotional side. Cancer is a mental struggle. You have to remember who you are, you are a friend, a daughter, maybe a mother a sister, a wife, you are more than a breast. Those who know and love you will show you this, keep hold of that and when you already you can always have reconstruction. Love. And hugs, Carol xxxx
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi, I agree, yes it can be a nightmare. You say you don't feel brave or strong, and that is fine, it is okay to felel scared and overwhelmed. Try to take it as it comes. You will have the surgery because you have no choice and that knowledge will give you strength, you may not feel it right now but you are stronger than you know.   I have had a few shaky moments this week too. I have not really totally recovered from the last infusion and am due for cycle 4 on Tuesady. This may sound weird, but watching Eddie Izzard, run 27 marathons in 27 days was an inspiration, when people asked him how he did it he said, " it's all in the head, I just kept saying to myself," keep going." Don't let your mind go to the dark side. You control your mind. You can do this, one step, one day at a time. Feel the love that is all around you and bathe in the light. YOU CAN DO THIS❤️ Love, Carol xxx
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi there, I had a mastectomy in December. I'd already had a lumpectomy so was prepared, it is the unknown that is scary. They will take you to a pre surgery room, and pump some medication into your vein. You are talking with them,chatting about this and that and the next thing is you wake up and it's all over! I had no  nausea from the anaesthetic, and had no physical pain from the incision, the drains caused me more discomfort, because they are something foreign in your body, but they came out painlessly after a day. You are having reconstruction so it will be different for you, but they will control any pain with medication and each day you will feel stronger and better. Good luck. Carol xxxx
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy and recon on Thursday sacred!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi there, This time last year, I was in a similar position to you. I had found a lump, went to the GP, who referred me to the breast clinic. Ultrasound, biopsy, consultant no too worried, the lump was smooth on the edges, he said cancerous lumps were usually jagged, but I would get the results in 10 days. Cancer. So the journey began and now it is over. You are at the scary stage, so many unknowns, so many thoughts racing through your head, the fear of dying, the disbelief, it is all normal and its how the cancer roller coaster begins. But you will survive and time will pass and you will be like me, getting on with your life again!...and after rereading your post you do t even have a diagnosis yet, so you might be lucky and it is not cancer. Carolxxxxxx
Posts.Title: I'm 43 saw a dimpling on the breast and went for a routine referr...
